title: 111_hr2110
content: The Act is titled the "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" and limits state withholding and taxation of employee income. The "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" limits state income tax to the employee's residence state and the state where they work for more than 30 days in a calendar year. Income earned in a year is only subject to state income tax withholding and reporting if the employee meets the criteria outlined in the Act. The "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" states that income earned in a calendar year is subject to state income tax withholding and reporting if the employee works in a state for more than 30 days. Employers can rely on an employee's determination for state income tax withholding and information return obligations. The Act requires state income tax withholding for wages earned in a calendar year if an employee works in a state for more than 30 days. Employers can rely on an employee's time estimate for tax obligations, except in cases of fraud or collusion. The Act allows employers to rely on an employee's time estimate for tax obligations, except in cases of fraud or collusion. Records maintained by an employer for other business purposes do not override an employee's determination. The Act allows employers to rely on an employee's time estimate for tax obligations, except in cases of fraud or collusion. Employers can use data from a time and attendance system to track employee duties instead of relying on the employee's determination. The Act allows employers to use a time and attendance system to track employee duties instead of relying on the employee's determination. An employee will be considered present in a State if they perform the majority of their duties there for the day. An employee will be considered present and performing employment duties within a State for a day if they perform the majority of their duties in that State for that day. If an employee performs material employment duties in a resident state and one nonresident state during one day, they will be considered to have performed the majority of their duties in the nonresident state for that day. An employee performing material employment duties in a resident state and one nonresident state during one day will be considered to have performed the preponderance of their duties in the nonresident state for that day. The term "employee" is defined by the State in which the duties are performed. Transit time does not apply in determining the location of an employee's performance of employment duties. (C) The portion of the day an employee is in transit does not apply in determining the location of their employment duties. The term "employee" is defined by the State where duties are performed, excluding professional athletes, entertainers, and certain public figures. A professional athlete is someone who performs services in a professional athletic event. The term "employee" is defined by the State where duties are performed, excluding professional athletes and entertainers. A professional athlete is someone who performs services in a professional athletic event, while a professional entertainer performs services in the professional performing arts for wages. The term "certain public figures" refers to prominent individuals who are paid for services on a per-event basis in their capacity as public figures. The term "certain public figures" refers to individuals of prominence who are compensated for services at specific events, such as speeches or appearances. The term "employer" is defined as per the Internal Revenue Code or by the State where duties are performed. "State" refers to the various states in the US. "Time and attendance system" is a system where employees record their work hours. The term "time and attendance system" refers to a system where employees record their work location for each day worked outside their primary state, and the employer uses this data to allocate wages across different taxing jurisdictions. The term "wages or other remuneration" is defined by the state where employment duties are performed, and employees must record their work location for each day worked outside their primary state for wage allocation purposes. The Act will be effective on January 1, 2011.
